sentence.Network_en: By 1973 the government deficit equalled thirty per cent of GNP.
sentence.Network_cn: 到1973年，政府财政赤字相当于国民生产总值的30%。

sentence.Network_en: Almost ninety per cent of all rapes and violent assaults went unreported.
sentence.Network_cn: 几乎90%的强奸案和暴力侵害案都没有报案。

sentence.Network_en: "Prices are down 40 per cent since Christmas," he lamented.
sentence.Network_cn: “圣诞节以来物价降了4成，”他悲叹道。

derivation.yuyuan_name: late Middle English (in the sense 'a hundred'): from French cent, Italian cento, or Latin centum 'hundred'

entry.tran: 分(美元、欧元等的货币单位)
entry.def: A cent is a small unit of money worth one hundredth of some currencies, for example the dollar and the euro.

example.ex: A cup of rice which cost thirty cents a few weeks ago is now being sold for up to one dollar...
example.tran: 几个星期前卖30美分一杯的米饭，如今卖到1美元。

means.word_mean: 1. a fractional monetary unit of several countries
2. a coin worth one-hundredth of the value of the basic unit

example.en: The poor man claimed he didn't have a red cent.
example.zh: 那穷人声称他身无分文。

example.en: It didn't cost her a red cent.
example.zh: 那事儿没花过她一分钱。

per每+cent百,百分之一→每一百→百分之

in进入+cent唱+ive→把[力量]唱进去→激励

Sentence.sentence: Hetty saved every penny, eating in the cheapest restaurants for 15 cents.
They needn't pay a single cent for their power consumption on sunny days
For the past two months they haven't paid a cent.

jushi.english: There has been a uniform fare of ten cents for any distance ever since.
jushi.chinese: 从那以后不论远近车费一律是一角钱。

jushi.english: Traffic accidents have increased by five per cent in the past year.
The ferry hiked the fare to forty cents.
jushi.chinese: 渡口把船费提高到40美分。
